elements.title: Petite Mort (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Jiří Kylián's ballet Petite Mort (dancers pictured) uses slow movements from Mozart's most famous piano concertos to contrast the physicality of the choreography?

elements.title: Graham Fraser (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Graham Fraser pioneered cochlear implantation in the United Kingdom?

elements.title: Adelaide L. T. Douglas House (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the Adelaide L. T. Douglas House, built for a New York City socialite, housed the United States Olympic Committee before being sold to Guatemala?

elements.title: Mitch Love (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that ice hockey player Mitch Love once fought 34 times in one season, more than any other professional player in the world that year?

elements.title: BattleBit Remastered (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that BattleBit Remastered, a massively multiplayer online first-person shooter, was created by three indie developers?

elements.title: California TV station (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Chester Smith's California TV station ran its newscast on a "dental floss budget", as one former anchor put it?

elements.title: ecclesiastical prison (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that medieval monks could be punished by being walled up alive in a special ecclesiastical prison called the Vade in Pace?

elements.title: the best-selling novel of 1947 (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the best-selling novel of 1947 was described by Time magazine as "one of the worst ever published"?
